snippet: On Feb. 7, 1984, the Challenger space shuttle astronauts Bruce McCandless II and Robert L. Stewart performed the first untethered spacewalk during the STS-41B mission.
abstract: On Feb. 7, 1984, the Challenger space shuttle astronauts Bruce McCandless II and Robert L. Stewart performed the first untethered spacewalk during the STS-41B mission.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 7, 1984, two Challenger space shuttle astronauts, Capt. Bruce McCandless II and Col.l Robert L. Stewart, performed the first untethered spacewalk during the STS-41B mission. "Free of any lifeline and propelled into the dark void by tiny jets, they became, in effect, the first human satellites, " reported the Feb. 8 New York Times.Astronauts in every previous spacewalk, or extra-vehicular activity, had been attached to the spacecraft by a long cable. Captain McCandless and Colonel Stewart used 300-pound nitrogen-propelled backpacks known as manned maneuvering units to make their way through space. The men made two spacewalks during the mission, the second occurring on Feb. 9. The first lasted 5 hours 55 minutes and the second was 6 hours 17 minutes.

headline.main: Feb. 7, 1984 | NASA Astronauts Perform First Untethered Spacewalk
